string-array.name: str_Left_Science
string-array.item: Formulation of a question.\nThe question can refer to the explanation of a specific observation

Hypothesis.\nAn hypothesis is a conjecture, based on the knowledge obtained while formulating the question, that may explain the observed behavior of a part of our universe. The hypothesis might be very specific

Prediction.\nThis step involves determining the logical consequences of the hypothesis. One or more predictions are then selected for further testing. The less likely that the prediction would be correct simply by coincidence, the stronger evidence it would be if the prediction were fulfilled

Testing.\nThis is an investigation of whether the real world behaves as predicted by the hypothesis. Scientists (and other people) test hypotheses by conducting experiments. The purpose of an experiment is to determine whether observations of the real world agree with or conflict with the predictions derived from an hypothesis. If they agree, confidence in the hypothesis increases; otherwise, it decreases

Analysis.\nThis involves determining what the results of the experiment show and deciding on the next actions to take. The predictions of the hypothesis are compared to those of the null hypothesis, to determine which is better able to explain the data

string-array.name: str_Left_SCORE
string-array.item: S - Symptoms.\nThis is the most visible(by "external" calibration) and perceived as submitted by the Client aspects of the situation/experience; state existing on the date
C - Cause.\nExperience in the past, gave rise to the present state
O - Outcome.\nThe purpose of the changes or the state, which should replace the present state
R - Resources.\nElements of User Experience, the presence of which can solve the current situation; they make possible the transition from the present state to the desired
E - Effects.\nResponses/impact on the achievement of the results, for the client and for his significant environment, state in the future, when the result has already been achieved

string-array.name: str_Left_SMART
string-array.item: Business model specification of goals. SMART
S - Specific.\nThe first criterion stresses the need for a specific goal rather than a more general one. This means the goal is clear and unambiguous; without vagaries and platitudes

M - Measurable.\nThe second criterion stresses the need for concrete criteria for measuring progress toward the attainment of the goal. The thought behind this is that if a goal is not measurable, it is not possible to know whether a team is making progress toward successful completion

A - Attainable.\nThe third criterion stresses the importance of goals that are realistic and attainable. While an attainable goal may stretch a team in order to achieve it, the goal is not extreme. That is, the goals are neither out of reach nor below standard performance, as these may be considered meaningless
R - Relevant.\nThe fourth criterion stresses the importance of choosing goals that matter

T - Time-bound.\nThe fifth criterion stresses the importance of grounding goals within a time frame, giving them a target date. A commitment to a deadline helps a team focus their efforts on completion of the goal on or before the due date

string-array.name: str_Left_TOTE
string-array.item: T1 - Test 1.\nTest to obtain some representation of the problem state
O - Operate.\nOperate intervene in some way
T2 - Test 2.\nTest again to see if the desired result has been achieved. If it has not, loop back to operate. Compare T1 (desired) with T2 (current)
E - Exit.\nExit - problem solved. T1 = T2

string-array.name: str_Left_TricksOfLanguage
string-array.item: 1. Intention:\nWhat could be the positive intention?
2. Redefine:\nUse words that are similar but may infer something different. e.g. replace “irresponsible” with “careless” and “lay-offs” with “unable to adjust”
3. Consequences:\nFocus a consequence that leads to challenging the belief
4. Chunk down:\nLook at a specific element that challenges the belief.
5. Chunk Up:\nGeneralize in order to change the relationship defined by the belief.
6. Analogy:\nUse an analogy or metaphor that challenges the generalization defined by the belief.

7. Change Frame Size:\nRe-evaluate the implication of the belief in the context of a longer (or shorter) time frame, a larger number of people (or from an individual point of view) or a bigger or smaller perspective
8. Another Outcome:\nPropose a different outcome that challenges the relevancy of the belief.
9. Model of the World:\nLook at the belief from a different perspective (model of the world)
10. Reality Strategy:\nRe-assess the belief based on the fact that beliefs are based on specific perceptions
11. Another Outcome:\nPropose a different outcome that challenges the relevancy of the belief
12. Hierarchy of Criteria:\nRe-assess the belief based on a more important criterion
13. Apply to Self:\nUse key aspects of the belief to challenge the belief
14. Meta Frame:\nChallenge the basis for the belief. E.g. formulate a belief as to the origin of the belief

string-array.name: str_Left_AIDA
string-array.item: A - Attention (Awareness): attract the attention of the customer
I - Interest: raise customer interest by focusing on and demonstrating advantages and benefits (instead of focusing on features, as in traditional advertising)
D - Desire: convince customers that they want and desire the product or service and that it will satisfy their needs
A - Action: lead customers towards taking action and/or purchasing

string-array.name: str_Left_Eye
string-array.item: Eye movement to the left or right for many people seems to indicate if a memory was recalled or constructed.

string-array.name: str_Left_VAK
string-array.item: Visual thoughts(V) - sight, mental imagery, spatial awareness
Auditory (or linguistic) thoughts(A) - sound, speech, dialog, white noise
Kinesthetic (or proprioceptive) sense(K) - somatic feelings in the body, temperature, pressure, and also emotion
